greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Define a sequence c depending on n by: c(1)=1 and c(2)=n; c(k+2) = (c(k+1) + c(k))/2 if c(k+1) and c(k) have the same parity; otherwise c(k+2)=abs(c(k+1)-2*c(k)); sequence gives values of n such that lim k -> infinity c(k) = infinity.
comment: If c(2) is even then c(k) = 1 for k >= 2*c(2), hence there is no even value in the sequence. If n is in the sequence, there is an integer k(n) and an integer m(n) such that for any k >= k(n) c(2k)-c(2k-1) = 2*m(n) and c(2k+1)-c(2k)=-m(n). Sometimes m(n) = (n-1)/2 but not always. If B(n) = a(n+1)-a(n) then B(n) = 2 or 4, but B(n) does not seem to follow any pattern.
Conjecture: this sequence gives the positions of 0's in the limiting 0-word of the morphism 0->11, 1->10, A285384.  - _Clark Kimberling_, Apr 26 2017
Conjecture: This also gives the positions of the 1's in A328979. - _N. J. A. Sloane_, Nov 05 2019
example: if c(2)=41 -> c(3)= 21 ->c(4)= 31 ->c(5)= 26 ->c(6)= 36 ->c(7)= 31 ->c(8)= 41 ->c(9)= 36 then c(2k)-c(2k-1)= 10 c(2k+1)-c(2k) = - 5 for k >=2 implies that c(k) -> infinity hence 41 is in the sequence.
results.author: _Benoit Cloitre_, Aug 12 2002
